Note:
The verses are the same in each of two variant contexts in the Fasciculus: see Wenzel (1978)
XWenzel, Siegfried. Verses in Sermons: ‘Fasciculus morum’ and Its Middle English Poems. Cambridge, MA: Medieval Academy of America, 1978, 158-9, 193-4.
_description: Love God, thyself, thy friend and thy foe (4 lines), a tag in the Fasciculus morum

Bod187.Transcription:
þu loue god ouer all þyngsythen þy selue with oute
                    synnyngAfter þy frende as kynde þe techeAnd þenne
                    þy foo with outen wreche

Bod410.Transcription:
Than loue god ouer all thyngSithyn þi self with oute
                    synnyngSithyn þi frend or kynyng techet And þenne þi fo
                    with oute wreche

BodLauMis111.Transcription:
Loue god þu man ouer all thingeSithen thy self with oute
                    sinningSithen þy frynde as kynde the tethAfterward þy foo
                    with outyn any wreth

BodLauMis213.Transcription:
thu loue god ouer alle thyngesithen thi self withoute
                    synnyngSithen thi ffrende as knynge techethAnd then thi ffo withouten
                    wreche

BodRawC670.Transcription:
Þow loue god ouer all þingSyþyn þy selfe
                    with-owte synyngSyþyn þy frende as kynd þe
                    techeÞan þy foo with outen wreche
BodRawC670.Editions:
Wenzel,  Siegfried. 
             Verses in Sermons: ‘Fasciculus morum’ and Its Middle
                English Poems.
         Cambridge, MA: Medieval Academy of America, 1978: 193.

CamGon71.Transcription:
þu loue god ouer all thyngbe þi selue wyth outen
                    synnyngSychen þi frend os kynd þe teche& þen
                    þi foo wyth outen wreche

CamGon364.Transcription:
Loue god ouer al þyngStheyn þi self with outen
                    sinnyngSethyn þi frend as kende techytAfterward þi foo with
                    outen wreche
CamGon364.Note:
B context. Second occurrence in this MS, listed as a variant text by
                        Wenzel (1978)
XWenzel,  Siegfried. 
             Verses in Sermons: ‘Fasciculus morum’ and Its Middle
                English Poems.
         Cambridge, MA: Medieval Academy of America, 1978, p. 193, but actually just the usual text (Wenzel
                    does not note the first occurrence).

CamStJohn159.Transcription:
Þou luf god owr all thyngeSithene þi self with owtyn
                    syningeSithene þi frende as kynde þe techÞan Þi
                    foo wyt owtyn wrech

NLS18721.Transcription:
[Loue] God ouer alle þinggeHimself withouten wemme of
                    senninggeHis euene cristene as kinde þe wile techeÞi fo
                    withouten wiling of oni wreche
NLS18721.Note: Occurs separately in Grimestone’s sermon notebook.
NLS18721.Editions:
Wilson,  Edward. 
             A Descriptive Index of the English Lyrics in John of Grimestone’s
                Preaching Book.
Medium Ævum Monographs
         n.s. 2. Oxford, 1973: 19.

EDU82.Transcription:
love thou god ouer all thyngSen thy self wyth owte synnyngSen
                    thy frende as kynde the techeAfter thy foo wyth owte wreche

Spalding.Transcription:
thowe lufe god ouer all th[ing]Syn thi selfe wythout synnyngSyne
                    thi frende als kynde the techeAnd than thi foo wythouten wrech

WorcF19.Transcription: Now y haue þat i wellgodis grame in þy bill
